article_title: The Bombardment of Casablanca and the French Occupation

paragraphs.text: The French presence in Morocco intensified in the early 20th century, marked by increasing disorder and intervention . The Conference of Algeciras (January 16 to April 7, 1906) strengthened France's economic and military position in Morocco . However, internal unrest persisted, leading to the Treaty of Fez on March 30, 1912, which established the French Protectorate . This protectorate granted France administrative, political, and military control over Morocco . The actual conquest and pacification of the country took twenty-two years after the signing of the treaty . Even before the formal establishment of the protectorate, tensions were rising. The murder of Dr. Émile Mauchamp in Marrakech on March 19, 1907, served as a pretext for French military action . Hubert Lyautey used this event as justification for the French occupation of Oujda, a significant step in establishing the protectorate .

On July 30, 1907, nine Europeans were massacred in Casablanca, precipitating the French decision to occupy the city . This massacre prompted the French government to send the warship 'Galilée' to protect the French consulate and French nationals . On August 5, 1907, the 'Galilée' landed a small troop of 66 men, who faced gunfire at the Porte de la Marine . This landing led to fighting and the subsequent bombardment of Casablanca . The decision to bombard the city was met with criticism from other powers and members of the French parliament . A French expeditionary force was concentrated at Oran and escorted to Casablanca by warships . The expeditionary force, consisting of 2,000 men under General Drude, landed in Casablanca on August 7, 1907, at noon, replacing the marines . The VI/1er RE (Foreign Legion) also landed on August 7 to defend against attacks from the Chaouia tribes . The French bombardment of Casablanca is depicted in the postcard 'La France au Maroc', showing the carnage .

sections.subtitle: The French Occupation and Colonial Administration

paragraphs.text: Following the bombardment, Casablanca came under French control . The French were responsible for maintaining order in the city after the 1907 riots . The French occupation of Morocco, including Casablanca, was interrupted by World War I (1914-1918) but resumed methodically in 1920 . The French faced resistance in various regions, including the Middle Atlas, south of the Grand Atlas, and the region of Taza . Casablanca served as a base to subdue the Chaouia tribes . The French colonial administration introduced modern public health measures and work discipline . Colonial settings, like Morocco, were used to experiment with welfare society norms before they were implemented in France . French urban planning in Morocco during the colonial period involved two approaches: "techno-cosmopolitanism" and "middling modernism" . "Techno-cosmopolitanism" aimed to integrate general planning principles with specific cultural and social contexts, operationalizing history, society, and culture . Modernization under French colonialism involved identifying and operationalizing Moroccan tradition to achieve health, productivity, and efficiency .

sections.subtitle: World War II and Operation Torch

paragraphs.text: Following France's defeat by Nazi Germany in June 1940, Morocco, as a French protectorate, fell under Axis dominion . Casablanca came under Vichy authority . Marshal Philippe Pétain, head of the Vichy regime, also led France's colonial possessions, including Morocco . In November 1942, Anglo-American forces landed in French North Africa as part of Operation Torch . The Allied landing occurred on November 8, 1942 . General Eisenhower was the Commander in Chief of Operation Torch . The operation aimed to capture Casablanca, Oran, Algiers, and Tunis . French Casablanca came under bombardment early in the morning of November 7 by American admirals . American troops advanced towards Casablanca on land along the Casablanca-Rabat highway against French artillery fire . Allied forces defeated the Vichy resistance in Casablanca after an intense bombardment from November 8-11 . French Casablanca surrendered on November 11 after experiencing heavy losses . After the victory against Axis defenders, the Americans allowed the French to temporarily hold power in Casablanca . The Vichy French were defeated in Morocco, ending Axis rule in the region .

sections.subtitle: The Casablanca Conference and Moroccan Nationalism

paragraphs.text: The Allies convened the Casablanca Conference from January 14-24, 1943 . President Roosevelt and Churchill met with Resident General Noguès and Sultan Sidi Mohammed Ben Youssef . President Franklin D. Roosevelt visited Moroccan King Muhammad V in a suburb of Casablanca and promised him independence . Roosevelt's promise generated a wave of Moroccan nationalism . The support of the United States and the United Kingdom for Moroccan independence angered French authorities . In 1945, a famine occurred in Morocco, for which the French did nothing, while the Americans offered food aid . Muhammad V praised the American government in Tangier, ignoring praise to the French government, in the presence of French officials . France exiled Muhammad V in 1952, causing the citizens of Morocco to associate their nationalism with Muhammad V’s exile . France restored Muhammad V to the throne after facing public disapproval and a revolution in Morocco . In 1955, Muhammad V met with the French Foreign Minister in Paris and declared the end of a “minor jihad” to gain independence .

Casablanca came under Vichy authority in June 1940 . Sultan Sidi Mohammed ben Youssef signed decrees on August 5, 1941, mirroring Vichy's anti-Jewish laws, restricting Jewish professional options, education, and residence . In November 1941, Moroccan Jews were to cease practicing prohibited professions or face imprisonment and fines, though exemptions were possible . Léon René Sultan lost his French citizenship and was disbarred due to Vichy laws; he continued to advocate against the protectorate authorities . Forced labor camps in Morocco housed Eastern European Jews and political prisoners, with approximately 7,000 prisoners, about one-third Jewish, building the Trans-Saharan Railway . Hélène Cazes Benatar established the Moroccan Refugee Aid Committee to assist refugees in Morocco during the Vichy period . President Roosevelt met with Resident General Noguès in Casablanca in January 1943 and expressed views on limiting the number of Jews in professions in North Africa .

After the Allied liberation in November 1942, Algerian Jews like Leon Sultan had to wait months to regain French citizenship and Moroccan Jews to regain employment and living quarters . Léon René Sultan founded the Moroccan Communist Party in 1943 . The Istiqlal party released its Manifesto of Independence in Morocco on January 11, 1944, demanding independence under Sultan Sidi Mohammed Ben Youssef . Jacques Lemaigre Dubreuil actively participated in the "African resistance" and helped prepare the way for the Allied landings in November 1942 . He was assassinated in Casablanca on June 11, 1955, by French "counter-terrorists" due to his support for Moroccan independence . By 1956, Morocco gained its independence .

sections.subtitle: The French Air Force in Morocco

paragraphs.text: The French military aviation dates back to 1909 . During World War II, Curtiss P-40F Warhawks were delivered to Casablanca, French Protectorate of Morocco on January 9, 1943, for the Aviation of the Army of Africa of Giraud . During Operation Torch, French Curtiss H.75 Hawks opposed US Navy F4F Wildcats . The French Air Force was also involved in the Algerian War (1952-1962) .

sections.subtitle: The Spanish Red Cross and French Competition

paragraphs.text: Following the French naval bombardment of Casablanca in 1907, the Société de Secours aux Blessés Militaires (SSBM) sent a group of twelve nurses to Casablanca . Inès de Bourgoing, who later became the wife of Maréchal Lyautey, was among the nurses sent to Casablanca in 1907 . The Spanish Red Cross was marginalized by French competition in French-controlled Casablanca .
